subject: Re: Alphabetical Order
msgSnippet: ... This is the way it works already and the proposal I ve put forward won t change it. ... Yes, that is exactly the implication. Awe would play a dual role of
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
>So you're saying that we who have CLOTH = THOUGHT and LOT = PALM (a
>large minority of Americans and a small minority of Brits) should use
>Awe for the first and Ah for the second
>

This is the way it works already and the proposal I've put forward
won't change it.

>
>whereas those with CLOTH = LOT,
>THOUGHT, PALM (current RP speakers) should use Awe for the first two and
>Ah for the third, is that right?
>

Yes, that is exactly the implication. Awe would play a dual role of
/O/ and /Q/. This is not totally unprecedented: some letters like
#26It already do this sort of thing to facilitate morphemic writing.
Certainly between accents, QS letters already have different sounds.

>
>But what about CLOTH = LOT, THOUGHT = PALM
>folks (most Canadians)? Are they too to use Awe for the first
>and Ah for the second?
>

Yes. For them, nothing about Ah changes. In the old lexical set
arrangement, they used Ox for CLOTH and LOT, under the new they would
use Awe for those letters.
Since QS letters are not phonetic, such a change is irrelevant. Nor is
it unprecedented, even under the old arrangement a Bostonian uses
#32Ah for /Q/ while RP uses #34Ox

>
>Finally, what about Scottish English speakers,
>who (IIRC) have CLOTH = THOUGHT, LOT, PALM?
>

In this case the only change is that LOT would be spelled with Awe
instead of Ox which is I think the same kind of issue as the Canadian
mentioned above.


I might add also that all the proscriptions involving Roe (NEAR,
SQUARE, NURSE etc) are already free of Ox and so would not be affected.


For clarity I've put together this file:

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/fig5.jpg




--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> Anthony Grahn scripsit:
>
> > 1. Use Awe for the THOUGHT, CLOTH and LOT lexical sets when they do
> > not merge with PALM.
>
> So you're saying that we who have CLOTH = THOUGHT and LOT = PALM (a
> large minority of Americans and a small minority of Brits) should use
> Awe for the first and Ah for the second, whereas those with CLOTH = LOT,
> THOUGHT, PALM (current RP speakers) should use Awe for the first two and
> Ah for the third, is that right? But what about CLOTH = LOT, THOUGHT
> = PALM folks (most Canadians)? Are they too to use Awe for the first
> and Ah for the second? Finally, what about Scottish English speakers,
> who (IIRC) have CLOTH = THOUGHT, LOT, PALM?
>
> (Remember that CLOTH is always either merged with THOUGHT or with LOT.)
>
> --
> It was dreary and wearisome. Cold clammy winter still held way in this
> forsaken country. The only green was the scum of livid weed on the dark
> greasy surfaces of the sullen waters. Dead grasses and rotting
reeds loomed
> up in the mists like ragged shadows of long-forgotten summers.
> --"The Passage of the Marshes"
http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
>
